member.name: T:Gentle.Common.CacheStrategy
member.summary: This enumeration is used to apply a caching strategy to objects.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.CacheStrategy.Never
member.summary: This value indicates that caching is disabled.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.CacheStrategy.Temporary
member.summary: This value indicates that caching is enabled, and that cached objects may be collected and released at will by the garbage collector. This is the default, but can be overridden by setting the Options/Cache/DefaultCacheStrategy key in the configuration file.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.CacheStrategy.Permanent
member.summary: This value indicates that caching is enabled, and that cached objects may not be garbage collected. The developer must manually ensure that objects are removed from the cache when they are no longer needed. This strategy is applied to the default PersistenceBroker instance used by the Broker class in order to ensure it is never garbage collected.

member.name: T:Gentle.Common.ICacheKeyProvider
member.summary: This interface should be implemented by all types that are cached. It allows the cache to identify the key for the object which speeds up removal dramatically.

member.name: P:Gentle.Common.ICacheKeyProvider.CacheKey
member.summary: The key used to identify the item in the cache.

member.name: T:Gentle.Common.UniqingScope
member.summary: This enumeration is used to select the scope within which to ensure object uniqing. This is only appliccable when object caching is enabled.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.UniqingScope.WebSession
member.summary: This value indicates that objects are uniqued within the scope of an ASP.NET web session. If no session exists Application scope is used.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.UniqingScope.Thread
member.summary: This value indicates that objects are uniqued within a thread. This is the default scope.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.UniqingScope.Application
member.summary: This value indicates that objects are uniqued within an application. It is up to the application developer to ensure thread safety.

member.name: T:Gentle.Common.ConfigKeyPresence

member.summary: This value is used to mark required configuration keys. An exception will be thrown if the key is not found during configuration of a type or instance.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.ConfigKeyPresence.Optional
member.summary: This value is used to mark optional configuration keys. No exception will be thrown if the key is missing from the configuration file.

member.name: T:Gentle.Common.ConfigurationAttribute
member.summary: Attribute with which to decorate members that need configuring. The configuration subsystem automatically converts the value to the proper type of the target. member.name: F:Gentle.Common.ConfigurationAttribute.requiredParameters

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.ConfigurationAttribute.keyPresenceRequirement
member.summary: This denotes whether the configuration key used for a configuration target is optional or mandatory. When mandatory (the default) an exception is raised if the specified key is not found in the configuration file.

The presence requirement of the specified key. Refer to for the available options.

member.summary: The XML path to the node containing the configuration value(s).

member.name: P:Gentle.Common.ConfigurationAttribute.RequiredParameters
member.summary: The number of callback method parameters whose presence is required in order for the method to be eligible for invocation. Only parameters after this number of parameters will be considered for null or default value substition.

member.name: P:Gentle.Common.ConfigurationAttribute.KeyPresenceRequirement

member.name: P:Gentle.Common.SystemSettings.Environment
member.summary: A unique string identifying the environment the current application is running in. The default value is "development". This is used to support storing multiple multiple configurations for different deployment environments in the same config file. The value of the environment is itself read from the config file using the path "MachineName/WebPath" (when not in web mode, WebPath is part of the directory path from which the application was started).

member.name: P:Gentle.Common.SystemSettings.WebPath

member.name: T:Gentle.Common.CallbackTarget
member.summary: This class is used for configuration elements that result in a method call. Use this target when you need to obtain a list of elements from the configuration file; the callback method will be called once for every node matching the path.

member.name: M:Gentle.Common.CallbackTarget.Configure(System.Object,System.Xml.XmlNode)
member.summary: Use the supplied XmlNode to configure the target object. This configuration target performs a method callback on the target object, and uses the attributes of the XmlNode as parameters. The method parameter names must match the names of the node attributes (a leading underscore will be stripped to permit using C# reserved words in the XML file). This method does not check whether the node matches the requested environment.
member.param: The object to cofigure.
The node containing the configuration value(s).

member.name: M:Gentle.Common.CallbackTarget.Configure(System.Object,System.Xml.XmlNodeList)
member.summary: Use the supplied XmlNodes to configure the target object. This method filters the given list of nodes by environment before applying them individually. All nodes matching the current environment AND all nodes not limited by an environment attribute are used for configuration.
member.param: The object to cofigure.
The list of nodes containing the configuration value(s).

member.summary: Check whether the specified tracer string occurs in the stack trace of the call leading to the exception. This method excludes the last three method calls from the stack trace analysis, assuming that the exception was provoked by a call to one of the Check.Verify or Check.Fail methods.

The exception whose call stack is to be inspected.
member.returns: True if the tracer is found in the stack trace.

Skip this number of stack frames from the search.
member.returns: True if the tracer is found in the stack trace.

summary.p: This enumeration lists all common error conditions, their severity and a default error message.
Unspecified errors or errors with no severity attribute are treated as critical.
At this time almost all errors have been brainlessly classified as critical pending a review at some future time.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.DatabaseUnavailable
member.summary: This error is used when no connection to the database server could be established. This is usually caused by errors in the connection string, but can also be due to network or database server problems.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.DeveloperError
member.summary: This error is used when an error in the use of Gentle was detected (e.g. invalid use of or missing custom attributes). No default message is provided for this error (if used via the Check class the first argument will be used as format string for remaining arguments).

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.EmptyListParameter
member.summary: This error is used when a list parameter with content (i.e. not null and with at least one element) was expected.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.InvalidNullValue
member.summary: This error is used when a DateTime has an invalid NullValue.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.InvalidProviderLibrary
member.summary: This error is used when Gentle fails to load a provider library defined in the configuration file.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.InvalidRequest
member.summary: This error is used when Gentle detects an invalid request, such as trying to execute a missing stored procedure. It is also used when a request cannot be satisfied (e.g. trying to obtain an SqlStatement from SqlBuilder before all required information has been set).

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.InvalidType
member.summary: This error is used when an object is added to a TypedArrayList, and the objects type does not match the type specified when the list was created.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.MissingConfigurationKey
member.summary: This error is used when Gentle fails to find a matching node (for a required setting) in the configuration store.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NoColumnForMember
member.summary: This error is used when Gentle finds a member (field or property) carrying the TableColumn attribute that references a non-existing column.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NoDefaultProvider
member.summary: This error is used when the Broker class is used and no DefaultProvider was defined in the configuration file.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NoIdentityReturned
member.summary: This error is used when a row identity was expected but none was received. This usually only happens if the analyzer has been disabled (or is incomplete for the provider used) and the table definition is out of sync with the TableName attribute definition used.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NoNewConnection
member.summary: This error is used when no new connection to the database server could be established. This is usually caused by a resource leak that drains the connection pool before the GC can reclaim them, but can also be caused by a variety of other problems.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NoObjectMapForTable
member.summary: This error is used when no type is associated with a table (the available databases are enumerated by the analyzer when in "Full" mode). Errors of this type can safely be ignored.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NoProperty
member.summary: This error is used when no member was found with the specified name. This usually occurs due to spelling or case sensitivity errors in string parameters.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NoPropertyForNotNullColumn
member.summary: This error is used when a column is found that does not permit null values, yet the type to which it maps does not have a member mapping to this column. This error is thrown by the database analyzer in order to prevent later errors when trying to insert to the table.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NoProviders
member.summary: This error is used when no database provider libraries were defined in the configuration.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NoSuchParameter
member.summary: This error is used when a non-existing query parameter is referenced. This usually occurs due to spelling or case sensitivity errors.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NoSuchRecord
member.summary: This error is used when no matching database record was found. This can be the result of a concurrency error or due to invalid parameter values.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NoConfigStoreFound
member.summary: This error is used when no configuration store could be found. Gentle tries to obtain its configuration from both the standard .NET configuration file (using the class to read the <gentle> section) and the standalone Gentle.config file.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NoSuchView
member.summary: This error is used when a non-existing view is referenced. This usually occurs due to spelling or case sensitivity errors in parameters from client-side code.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NotImplemented
member.summary: This error is used when the requested method has not yet been implemented. This usually occurs due to incomplete development code being accessed.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NullParameter
member.summary: This error is used when a null parameter is passed to a method that does not permit null values. This usually occurs due to errors in client-side code.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NullIdentity
member.summary: This error is used when trying to set the identity value on a class, but the class does not have an identity column.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NullProperty
member.summary: This error is used when a member was null, but a not-null value was required. This usually occurs due to errors in client-side code.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.NullWithNoNullValue
member.summary: This error is used when a column contained a null value and the corresponding member does not permit null values. This usually occurs due to a missing NullValue declaration on the TableColumn attribute of the member.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.PropertyReadOnly
member.summary: This error is used when a property is read-only, but write access was required. This can usually be corrected by moving the TableColumn attribute to the underlying member, or by adding a setter for the property.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.PropertyWriteOnly
member.summary: This error is used when a property is write-only, but read access was required. This can usually be corrected by moving the TableColumn attribute to the underlying member, or by adding a getter for the property.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.StatementError
member.summary: This error is used when statement execution fails. This is usually due to syntax errors in the specified SQL string.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.UnknownAssembly
member.summary: This error is used when an assembly name cannot be resolved to an Assembly instance. This may occur due to missing project references or invalid location of the required DLL. When the Inheritance attribute is used it may also occur due to invalid names in the database column storing the full type name.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.UnknownProvider
member.summary: This error is used when a provider cannot be found in the list of registered providers. This usually occurs due to a missing entry (or incorrect name) in the configuration file.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.UnknownTable
member.summary: This error is used when a type references a table that does not exist. This usually occurs due to spelling or case sensitivity errors in the declaration of the TableName attribute.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.UnexpectedRowCount
member.summary: This error is used when the returned number of rows does not match the expected count. This can be due to concurrency (record changed by another process) or parameter value errors.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.Unspecified
member.summary: This error is used for unclassified errors of all kinds.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.UnsupportedColumnType
member.summary: This error is used when an unsupported database type is encountered during analysis of the database schema.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.UnsupportedConfigStoreUri
member.summary: This error is used when an explicit configuration file path (location of Gentle.config) was specified in the AppSettings section of the .NET configuration file, yet the path specified was not valid. This can be due to errors in the URI, an illegal path, or an unsupported destination (only files are supported).

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.UnsupportedDatabaseFunction
member.summary: This error is used when an unsupported database function is called.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.UnsupportedPropertyType
member.summary: This error is used when an unsupported member type is encountered. To correct the error you must remove the TableColumn attribute, or move it to a member of a different type.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.UnsupportedType
member.summary: This error is used when an unsupported type is passed as argument to a method that required the type to be supported. This usually occurs due to a missing TableName attribute on the class declaration, but can also be remedied by having the class implement the ITableName interface.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.ViewError
member.summary: This error is used when an error occurred during generation of a custom view.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Error.Validation
member.summary: This error is used when a business object contains an incorrect value.

member.name: T:Gentle.Common.GentleException
member.summary: The exception class thrown by classes in the Gentle.Framework namespace. Because all new infomation resides in the ExceptionInfo descendant the Exception class itself doesn't add anything new.

member.name: P:Gentle.Common.GentleException.Error
member.summary: The Error enum specifies the error class and is also used to obtain the message used.

member.name: P:Gentle.Common.GentleException.Severity
member.summary: The severity of the error leading to this exception.

member.name: M:Gentle.Common.GentleException.ToString
member.summary: Returns the current GentleException and all nested exceptions as a multiline string.

member.name: T:Gentle.Common.GentleStatistics
member.summary: Singleton used to store various statistical information (counters).

member.summary: Return the number of successful attempts at looking up something in the cache.

member.name: P:Gentle.Common.GentleStatistics.CacheMisses
member.summary: Return the number of unsuccessful attempts at looking up something in the cache.

member.name: P:Gentle.Common.GentleStatistics.UniqingCount
member.summary: Return the number of successful attempts at object uniqing. This number effectively represents the number of object constructions skipped due to a cache hit.

member.name: P:Gentle.Common.GentleStatistics.SkippedQueries
member.summary: Return the number of successful attempts at resolving a query without contacting the database.

member.name: P:Gentle.Common.GentleStatistics.CacheSize
member.summary: Return the number of items currently in the cache.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Severity.Error
member.summary: This severity level is used for error messages.

member.name: F:Gentle.Common.Severity.Critical

member.summary: This severity level is used for messages whose severity has not been classified. In most cases this corresponds to the Debug classification.

summary.p: The namespace contains code used by but not specific to Gentle.
The TypedArrayList folder contains a typed version of the .NET Framework ArrayList class. The advantage against the standard is, that the could be bound to a DataGrid control without restrictions.

Although it is possible to bind a standard ArrayList to a DataGrid control you will not be able to add or remove rows or to sort the data because the standard ArrayList doesn't implement the needed interfaces and .

To make the binding more comfortable, the namespace contains some attributes which changes the default behaviour of the binding process of the DataGrid control. If you use the attributes you are able to

item.description: define user defined column headers with the
allow / disallow sorting of specific columns with the

summary.p: The code is based on the article "Sammelleidenschaften" in the dot.net Magazin 02/2003 by Thomas Fenske.

member.summary: Invoke the best available match (from a list of methods available) for the supplied parameters. If no method can be called using the supplied parameters, an exception is raised. Any exceptions raised by the called method will be logged and then re-thrown.

A hashtable of parameter name/value pairs. All parameters given must be used in the method call in order for a method to be considered.
member.returns: The return value of the invocation.

member.name: T:Gentle.Common.MethodInvokable
member.summary: This class wraps a single invokable method call. It contains information on the method to call as well as the parameters to use in the method call. This intermediary class is used by the MethodDispatcher to select the best match to call from a given set of available methods (and a single set of parameter values).

member.name: T:Gentle.Common.Attributes.AllowSortAttribute
member.summary: Controlling the Sorting capbility of a column in a DataGrid control.

remarks.p: This attribute is intended to uses with the class. For the objects contained in the TypedArrayList you can determine if a property of the object may act as a sortable column in the corresponding DataGrid control.
Per default (if the attribute isn't used) sorting capability is enabled.

member.name: M:Gentle.Common.Attributes.AllowSortAttribute.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Default constructor for the attribute.

tr.td: Sorting is enabled for the corresponding DataGrid column
Sorting is disabled for the corresponding DataGrid column

member.name: P:Gentle.Common.Attributes.AllowSortAttribute.Value
member.summary: Returns the current value of the attribute.
member.value: A boolean flag, which tells if the corresponding DataGrid column is sortable or not.

member.name: T:Gentle.Common.Attributes.CaptionAttribute
member.summary: Defining the caption of a column in a DataGrid control.

remarks.p: This attribute is intended to uses with the class. Per default the DataGrid control retrieve the names of all public property methods of the objects which are displayed in the DataGrid control by Reflection and uses them as column headers. The TypedArrayList use this attribute to display an alternative caption.

member.name: M:Gentle.Common.Attributes.CaptionAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Default constructor for the attribute.
member.param: The display name of the property in the column header of a DataGrid.

member.name: P:Gentle.Common.Attributes.CaptionAttribute.Value
member.summary: The attribute's value.
member.value: The column header text for a DataGrid.

member.name: T:Gentle.Common.Attributes.VisibleAttribute
member.summary: Controlling the visibility of a property in a DataGrid control.

remarks.p: This attribute is intended to uses with the class. For the objects contained in the TypedArrayList you can determine if the property should be visible in the DataGrid control.
Per default (if this attribute isn't present) all public properties of the objects contained in the TypedArrayList are visible columns in the DataGrid control.

If you set the visibility of a property in your class to false, you can't access it in the DataGrid control because there is no column for this property. If you want to access the property in the DataGrid you have to set the ColumnWidth of the DataGrid column to zero.

member.name: M:Gentle.Common.Attributes.VisibleAttribute.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Default constructor for the attribute.

tr.td: The property is a visible column in the DataGrid control
The property will not be shown in the DataGrid control

member.name: P:Gentle.Common.Attributes.VisibleAttribute.Value
member.summary: The attribute's value.
member.value: The column header text for a DataGrid.

member.name: T:Gentle.Common.RemoveEventHandler
member.summary: The RemoveEventHandler handles the cancellation of edit actions in a DataGrid control.
member.remarks: If the user cancels the data editing of a new line in the DataGrid, the event is fired and must be handled by the object which is being edited. The must be informed to remove the object from it's list. This will be done by firing a RemoveObject event in the CancelEdit event handler.

member.name: T:Gentle.Common.IBindable
member.summary: Interface for types which will be bound to a DataGrid using the .
member.remarks: All types stored in a which will be bound to a DataGrid control should implement this interface. It defines all methods and events needed to support the editing facilities of the DataGrid control.

member.name: E:Gentle.Common.IBindable.RemoveObject
member.summary: The event should be fired, if the user cancels the editing of a newly created object in the DataGrid control.

member.name: T:Gentle.Common.TypedArrayList
member.summary: A strongly typed ArrayList with binding capabilities.

remarks.p: Implemententation of a strongly typed array list of objects with full support for data binding (e.g. for use with a Datagrid control.

The TypedArrayList class implements the and interfaces to provide databinding to list controls like the DataGrid control with full support for adding and removing entries and sorting the displayed list.
The property methods of the types stored in the list can be flagged with a set of attributes to control the the behaviour of the data grid.

tr.td: Defines the caption of the column in the data grid.
(From ) Flags the column in the data grid as read-only.
Flags the column in the data grid as sortable.
Defines if the property is a visible column in the DataGrid control.

remarks.p: There is one restriction for the types stored in the TypedArrayList if you want to use the editing facilities of the DataGrid control. The types stored in the list must implement the interface. If you don't do this, adding and removing objects in the DataGrid will not work properly.
